div1.p:
-------------Field Note No. 14---------------
Pine Trees in Relation to Mosquito Production.

It has frequently been observed that certain pine trees
growing on the borders of impounded waters increased mosquito
production in these waters by furnishing protection to the mos-
quito larvae underneath and among the fallen pine leaves. There-
fore, the practice of ringing pine trees within fifty feet of
the water's edge has been recommended as the easiest way of
getting rid of the leaves which would fall during the mosquito
season. Recently an officer in the field reported that the
ringing of pine trees did not always cause the death of the trees,
and that unless properly and seasonably done the procedure might
prove harmful rather than beneficial as a means of mosquito
reduction.

In view of the fact that eleven different species of
pines occur in the southeastern United States, any one of which
might be encountered, and that there is considerable difference
among them in growth and time at which they shed their leaves,
it is hardly to be expected that all pine trees have the same
influence upon mosquito production.

Because of the practical importance of this matter each
officer in the field is requested to conduct a series of observa-
tions throughout the summer on:

(1) The influence of pine trees on mosquito production.
(2) The cheapest and quickest way of destroying pine
trees which are increasing mosquito production.

In order that there may be no confusion of the species under ob-
servation, you are being sent a list of the pines of this region
with a brief discription taken from Sargent's Manual of the Trees
of North America which may help in their identification. Each
officer in the field will be expected to submit notes on his ob-
servations at the end of the season, and it is hoped that every
important aspect of this study will be touched upon.

Pinus Strobus. White Pine: A tree 100 or more feet high at
maturity; bark thin on branches, 1 to 2 inches thick on old
trunk; wood light; leaves in 5-leaved clusters, soft bluish
green, from 3 to 5 inches long, turning yellow and falling in
autumn of their second season, or persisting until the follow-
ing summer. Distribution: Found in the Alleghany Mountains
and their foot hills.

Pinus palustris. Long-leaved Pine. Southern Pine: A tree 100
or more feet high at maturity; bark thin, 1/16 to 1/2 inch
thick on trunk, light orange-brown; wood heavy; leaves in
crowded 3-leaved clusters forming dense tufts at the ends of
the branches, slender, flexible, dark green in color, 8 to
18 inches long, deciduous at the end of their second year.
Distribution: Found in belt up to one-hundred and twenty-
five miles wide, stretching from southeast Virginia to
Floroda, thence to the Mississippi River and through east-
ern Louisiana and eastern Texas.

Pinus Caribaea, Slash Pine. Swamp Pine: A tree often 100 feet
high at maturity; bark thin, 1/2 to 3/4 inch thick on trunk,
shallow fissures, dark red-brown scales; wood heavy, rich in
pitch; leaves stout, in crowded 2 and 3-leaved clusters, 8 to
12 inches long, deciduous at the end of their second season.
Distribution: Coast region of South Carolina, southward to
Southern Florida and along Gulf Coast to Louisiana.

Pinus Taeda. Loblolly Pine. Old Field Pine: A tree generally
80 to 100 feet high at maturity; bark 3/4 to 1 1/2 inches thick
on trunk, bright red-brown; wood weak, brittle; leaves slen-
der, stiff, color pale green in 3-leaved clusters, 6 to 9
inches long, deciduous during their third year. Distribution:
Widely distributed throughout Middle, South Atlantic and
Gulf States.

Pinus rigida. Pitch Pine: A tree 50 to 60 feet high at
maturity, short trunk; bark thin, 3/4 to 1 1/2 inches thick
on trunk and greatly roughened; wood light and soft; leaves
dark yellow-green in 3-leaves clusters, 3 to 5 inches long,
deciduous during their second year. Distribution: Middle,
South Atlantic States and Alleghany region.

Pinus serotina. Pond Pine. Marah Pine: A tree usually 40
to 50 feet high at maturity; bark 1/2 to 3/4 inches thick,
dark red-brown, shallow fissures; wood soft, rich in pitch;
leaves in clusters of three or occasionally four, 6 to 8
inches long, deciduous during their third and fourth years.
Distribution: Wet, sandy flats or swamps along the Atlantic
Coast from North Carolina to Florida.

Pinus glabra. Spruce Pine. Cedar Pine: A tree usually 80 tO
100 feet high at maturity; bark 1/2 to 3/4 inches thick, red-
dish-brown, shallow fissures; wood soft; leaves slender, dark
greem 1 1/2 to 3 inches long, deciduous at the end of their sec-
ond and in the spring of their third year. Distribution:
South Carolina to central Florida and eastern Louisiana.

Pinus echinata. Yellow Pine. Short-leaved Pine: A tree
usually 80 to 100 feet high at maturity; bark 3/4 to 1-inch
thick, light cinnamon-red scales; wood variable in quality;
leaves in clusters of two or three, dark blue-green, 3 to 5
inches long, deciduous at the end of their second season and
dropping irregularly until their fifth year. Distribution:
Widely distributed throughout the Middle, South Atlantic
and Gulf States.

Pinus Virginiana. Scrub Pine: A tree usually 30 to 40 feet
high at maturity; bark 1/4 to 1/2 inches thick, shallow
fissures, dark brown scales, wood soft; leaves in two-leaved
remote clusters, gray green in color, 1 1/2 to 3 inches long,
gradually and irregularly deciduous during their third and
fourth years. Distribution: Middle and South Atlantic
States.

Pinus clausa. Sand Pine. Spruce Pine: A tree usually 15 to
20 feet high at maturity; bark 1/3 to 1/2 inch thick, narrow
deep fissures, bright red-brown scales; wood soft; leaves
slender in 2-leaved clusters, dark green in color, 2 to 3 1/2
inches long, deciduous during their third and fourth years.
Distribution: Gulf States near coast and narrow strip on
east coast of Florida.

Pinus pungens. Hickory Pine: A tree occasionally 60 feet
high at maturity; bark 3/4 to 1-inch thick, brown scales
tinged with red; wood soft; leaves in 2-leaved crowded
clusters, dark blue-green in color, 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 inches long,
deciduous during their second and third year. Distribu-
tion: Alleghany Mountains and foot hills.
